rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/709">        <title>A1_2 Single Photon Vision</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/709</link>            <description>This paper considers a hypothetical human eye capable of registering a single photon as a conscious image in the brain.\ufffd\ufffd To such an eye,\ufffd\ufffd a receding light source would not grow faint to the point of vanishing, but instead would eventually register in the brain as flickering of individual photons.\ufffd\ufffd The psychophysical concept of flicker fusion frequency is used to determine the threshold distance at which the receding light source ceases to appear continuous.\ufffd\ufffd Simple lasers with varying angular divergence are used to model the scenario.</description>            <dc:creator>Sam Turnpenney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Kieran Flatt</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Maria Garreffa</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>William Hunt Alexander Longman</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-10-28</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-10-28</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/715">        <title>A2_1 The Flash: Hero or Villain?</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/715</link>            <description><p>The CW Television Network\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds show \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Flash\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd depicts the titular character rescuing a cyclist from being hit by a car. This paper discusses whether the act of being saved by The Flash is in fact more damaging than being struck by a car. The results suggest that The Flash can be a hero but will have to alter either his speed or his method to lessen the impact on the victim.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Chris Checklin</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Robert Miller</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>James Anthony Farrow</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jeremy Hue</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-10-28</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-10-28</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/720">        <title>A5_1 Power of a Star in an Unreasonably Priced Car</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/720</link>            <description><p>The inaugural Formula E motor-racing championship features electric cars whose batteries are not currently capable of lasting an entire race, meaning drivers must change cars halfway through. This paper investigates the possibility of using solar panels to recharge the battery during the race; thereby ensuring only 1 car per driver is required. Whilst it is established that the car could support a sufficiently large solar array, the required area of 1920m<sup>2</sup> is clearly too large to be of practical use.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Roger Paul Leyser</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Hayley Jane Allison</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jordan Iain Penney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Giles Christopher Lipscombe</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-10-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-10-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/714">        <title>A5_2 Living in the Dark</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/714</link>            <description><p align="LEFT"><span style="font-size: small;">A body placed at the second Lagrangian point of\ufffd\ufffdmany host planets would not experience directly incident solar radiation; however, re-emissions from the host planet would impact the satellite. This paper looks into the time taken for the satellite to reach the temperature required for liquid water. Various host planets are considered and the radius of the satellite varied to examine the effect on the heating time. The paper finds that while a satellite around Earth would provide the longest habitable period, the time frame to reach a suitable temperature is the greatest. A satellite placed around a hot Jupiter would reach habitability the fastest. </span></p></description>            <dc:creator>Jordan Iain Penney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Giles Christopher Lipscombe</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Hayley Jane Allison</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Roger Paul Leyser</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-10-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-10-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/708">        <title>P4_1 Rendezvous With Rama: An analysis of the physics behind Arthur C. Clarke's science-fiction spaceship</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/708</link>            <description>This article investigates quantitatively the conditions described by a group of astronauts within a ship in the science-ction book Rendezvous with Rama by Arthur C. Clarke. It was found that the conditions would have allowed the astronauts to walk on the surface but breathing would be difficult.</description>            <dc:creator>Luke Ingram</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Lawrence Evans</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Daniel Cherrie</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Adam Tyler</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-10-31</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-10-31</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/707">        <title>A1_1 The Flat Earth's Escape Velocity</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/707</link>            <description>In some models, the Earth is considered to be a flat cylinder. Here we calculate the escape velocity for such a matter distribution and find that it is similar to the standard sphere. This result is briefly discussed and we show that, for large distances, the force from such a planet would tend to that from a sphere as expected.</description>            <dc:creator>Kieran Flatt</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Maria Garreffa</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>William Longman</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sam Turnpenney</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-10-31</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-10-31</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/721">        <title>A3_1 LED Refrigerator</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/721</link>            <description><p>This paper investigates the practicality of using LEDs with an efficiency of 230% as a way of cooling air inside a refrigerator. Using the standard dimensions of a household refrigerator and surrounding the entire surface area with the LEDs, how long would it take to reduce the temperature from 20\ufffd\ufffdC room temperature to 5\ufffd\ufffdC. We found that it would take 14.7 hours.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Michael Walker</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Tom Bradley</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Gregor McQuade</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Lee Garland</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-03</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-03</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/730">        <title>P2_2 Can Airheads Blow Minds?</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/730</link>            <description>The possibility of using helium gas inside the human head to make a person float was investigated using buoyancy and the ideal gas law. The volume of helium required to float was calculated as 63.7m3. When compressed down to the approximate size of a human head the pressure exerted was calculated as 2.23x109Pa. Since this was enough to destroy the skull, the minimum volume that the gas could be compressed to was calculated as 0.0678m3.</description>            <dc:creator>Thomas Griffiths</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Duleep Vasudevan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Katie Herlingshaw</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Mark Phillips</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/726">        <title>A4_4 Deeper Than Any Elephant Has Gone Before</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/726</link>            <description><p align="LEFT">\ufffd\ufffd</p><p><span style="font-size: medium;">In this paper, the depth of an Olympic size swimming pool required to crush an elephant is calculated. The depth of the swimming pool required to half the volume of an elephant was calculated to be 1.02 x 10</span><span style="font-size: xx-small;">6 </span><span style="font-size: medium;">m (1020km) equivalent to a pressure of 1.004 x 10</span><span style="font-size: xx-small;">10 </span><span style="font-size: medium;">Pa (approximately 100000 times that of atmospheric pressure). Although this is an overestimate, it shows the strength of bone. </span></p></description>            <dc:creator>Adam Higgins</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Alex Foden</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jonathan Sallabank</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Claire Sullivan</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-06</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-06</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/748">        <title>A5_5 Don\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt go to the Dark Side!</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/748</link>            <description><p>This paper investigates the assumptions made in \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdA5_2 Living in the Dark\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd as to whether a satellite at the second Lagrangian point will be completely in the shadow of its host planet. The paper finds that while this assumption holds to some degree for satellites in orbit about Mercury and a hot Jupiter at Mercury\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds orbital distance, a satellite at Earth\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds L2 point would still receive a portion of its flux directly from the Sun.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Jordan Iain Penney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Hayley Jane Allison</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Giles Christopher Lipscombe</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Roger Paul Leyser</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/738">        <title>A2_2 Dodging a Bullet</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/738</link>            <description><p>This paper discusses the possibility of a person being able to dodge a bullet through a quantum tunnelling event. A quantum mechanical approach was taken, modelling the bullet as a collection of individual atoms with identical wavelengths. The probability of tunnelling was then taken to be the collective probability of each atom tunnelling individually. The result obtained was (5.11E-19)(exp(-4.48E24)^(3.21E19)) which is effectively zero.</p></description>            <dc:creator>James Anthony Farrow</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jeremy Hue</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Robert Miller</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Chris Checklin</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/740">        <title>P2_4 Noah\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Ark: The Story Continues\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/740</link>            <description>This paper calculates the timeframes involved in the story of Noah\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds ark. Specifically, estimates of completely submerging the Earth in water and the subsequent evaporation of this water are obtained as 20.2 years and ~48,000 years respectively.</description>            <dc:creator>Katie Herlingshaw</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Mark Phillips</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Thomas Griffiths</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Duleep Vasudevan</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-12</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-12</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/725">        <title>A3_3 Pandoras Floating mountains</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/725</link>            <description><p>The mountains in the film Avatar are shown to naturally float in the air unaided by mechanical flight, this paper discuses whether this phenomenon could be created by the mountains containing superconducting materials and floating on the planets earth like magnetic field. The results show that a much larger field would be needed to float any material of a substantial size so the effect is not caused by this method.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Gregor McQuade</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Michael Walker</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Lee Garland</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Thomas Bradley</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-12</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-12</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/706">        <title>A4_1 It's a-me Density!</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/706</link>            <description>This paper considers the composition of small scale planets as seen in the video game Super Mario Galaxy. With an approximate radius for these planets set at 50m, the required density to maintain Earth-like surface gravity is calculated and compared to known super-dense structures such as white-dwarfs. The stability of such a planet is then discussed and it is concluded that it would likely explode due to the severe imbalance of gravitational pressure to degeneracy and coulomb pressures.</description>            <dc:creator>Claire Sullivan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jonathan Sallabank</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Adam Higgins</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Alex Foden</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-12</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-12</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/718">        <title>A4_2 Vaporising Earth</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/718</link>            <description>In this paper we explore the energies needed to completely vaporise the Earth. Taking into account the relative abundances of elements in the Earth and their latent heats of fusion and vaporisation, it is found that 6.41 x 1031J of energy (the equivalent of 7.82 x 1017kg of fissionable uranium) is needed to achieve this. It is found that this is not possible with modern day technologies, but may be possible in the future.</description>            <dc:creator>Adam Higgins</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Alex Foden</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jonathan Sallabank</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Claire Sullivan</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-14</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-14</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/734">        <title>P4_2 Tidal forces in the solar system</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/734</link>            <description><p align="LEFT">This article investigates the tidal accelerations exerted by planets on orbiting moons. The tidal acceleration was calculated, in terms of the acceleration due to gravity at the planet's surface, for several planetary systems in the solar system. A plot was created which showed that for most planetary systems, the tidal acceleration varied inversely as the cube of the semi-major axis, as theory predicted for the Earth and Moon.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Lawrence E. J. Evans</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Daniel Cherrie</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Luke Ingram</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Adam Tyler</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-15</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-15</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/750">        <title>P4_3 Shrinking the Earth</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/750</link>            <description><p align="LEFT">This article investigates the energy requirements to compress the Earth to within 1 km. This was done using a model assuming the compression to be elastic, and another model estimating the energy to overcome the Coulomb repulsion between the constituent protons. The energies found were 3.1x10<sup>32</sup> J and 8.3x10<sup>38</sup> J for each model respectively. It was also shown that to compress the Earth to within 1125 km you would have to overcome electron and neutron degeneracy pressure, and if compressed to a radius of 9 mm, the Earth would be a black hole.</p><p>\ufffd\ufffd</p></description>            <dc:creator>Lawrence E. J. Evans</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Daniel Cherrie</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Adam Tyler</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Luke Ingram</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-15</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-15</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/749">        <title>A1_9 Terraforming Mars: CO2 Combustion</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/749</link>            <description><p>This report examines the feasibility of transporting coal from the Earth to Mars to increase the Martian atmospheric density. This is done by releasing CO<sub>2</sub> through combustion, which would terraform the planet. It was found that this was unfeasible due to the large values required: 3.15 x 10<sup>19</sup> Kg of coal and 1.97x10<sup>27</sup> J of energy to transport it outside of the Earth\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds gravitational potential.</p></description>            <dc:creator>W.H.A. Longman</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Kieran Flatt</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sam Turnpenney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Maria Garreffa</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-16</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-16</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/735">        <title>A3_4 Jumping Into Orbit</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/735</link>            <description><p>The possibility of something (or someone) jumping from a moon or planet, directly into orbital motion, using only the initial thrust from the jump, is investigated. A physical model is created using IDL to plot paths of motion from a jump in order to do so. It was found that it is impossible to complete a full orbit of any body in space without landing or escaping gravitational pull.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Thomas Bradley</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Michael Walker</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Gregor McQuade</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Lee Garland</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-16</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-16</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/716">        <title>P2_1 The Skywalker Twins Drift Apart</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/716</link>            <description>An investigation into the effect of relative velocity and gravitational time dilation on twins was performed. For twins travelling 0.28 and 7 days respectively, at slightly different relativistic speeds, respective time dilations of 62.6 days and 1.92 years were calculated. With one twin on the surface of a gas giant and the other one hundred times further away in orbit the total time needed to rectify this age gap using gravitational time dilation was 9.77x10^6 years, which was therefore unfeasible.</description>            <dc:creator>Thomas Griffiths</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Duleep Vasudevan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Katie Herlingshaw</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Mark Phillips</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-18</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-18</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/743">        <title>A5_4 Water Under the Bridge</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/743</link>            <description><p align="LEFT">\ufffd\ufffd</p><p><span style="font-size: small;">This paper looks into Michael Faraday\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds attempted experiment in 1832 to determine whether he could detect a current from the interaction of the water in the River Thames with the Earth\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds magnetic field. The possibility of using such a current to power a 60W light bulb is then investigated. The paper finds that the current measured in the experiment is minimal to the degree that it would not have been detected and it would be implausible to power a light bulb from the effect. </span></p></description>            <dc:creator>Giles Lipscombe</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jordan Penney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Roger Leyser</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Hayley Jane Allison</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-20</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-20</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/722">        <title>P3_1 Just keep swimming</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/722</link>            <description><p style="margin: 0cm 1cm 0pt; text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: 'Calibri','sans-serif'; font-size: 10pt;">Investigation of the scene in the film \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdFinding Nemo\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in which a school of grouper fish are able to avoid being lifted out of the sea, after being captured in a fishing net. It is found that the total force acting on the wooden beam is 5323.7N which is less than the maximum force of 4x10<sup>5</sup>N which can be applied to the beam. </span></p></description>            <dc:creator>Poonam Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jessica Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Rutambhara Joshi</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-21</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-21</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/727">        <title>P3_2 Don\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt smoke and drive!</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/727</link>            <description><p>This paper investigates the consequences of smoking tobacco cigarettes in a car. With an average smoking rate of 5 minutes per cigarette and with no air entering or released from the car, we find that if the carbon monoxide (CO) content in the air is over 1000ppm, you would have to smoke approximately 32 cigarettes within the hour to fall unconscious from CO poisoning. Furthermore we consider whether opening a window would make it safe to smoke in a car as the air flow rate through the window would remove the CO content from the car.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Jessica Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Rutambhara Joshi</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Poonam Patel</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-21</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-21</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/739">        <title>P3_3 Fizzy Ocean!</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/739</link>            <description><p>This paper investigates the effect of the increasing levels of CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere, on it absorption into the oceans. We look at the temperature dependence of solubility of the CO<sub>2</sub> and whether the increasing levels absorbed would reach a similar amount to soda water, and turn the oceans fizzy.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Rutambhara Joshi</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jessica Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Poonam Patel</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-21</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-21</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/757">        <title>P3_4 Reducing blood loss through injury</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/757</link>            <description><p>On event of sustaining an injury which results in bleeding, it is advised to apply pressure on the wound and also elevate the injury above the height of the heart [1]. This paper investigates the physics behind the two actions, and shows that both cases result in the decreasing of the volumetric flow rate, and hence reduce the rate at which blood is lost. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd</p></description>            <dc:creator>Poonam Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jessica Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Rutambhara Joshi</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-21</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-21</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/759">        <title>P3_5 Balloon Mayhem in Gotham</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/759</link>            <description>The article investigates how high weather balloons made of helium rise before they burst and drop down to the Earth. Considering the pressure at higher altitudes, the radius of the balloon and the mass of the package we find that the balloon rises to an altitude of 37800m.</description>            <dc:creator>Jessica Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Poonam Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Rutambhara Joshi</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-21</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-21</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/732">        <title>A5_3 Are the Boots a Lie?</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/732</link>            <description><p>An investigation is described regarding the spring constant of the material used to create the boots worn by the leading character in the game \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdPortal\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. Within the game, the boots allow the character to fall from any height without injury. It is found that this is a possible feat using a spring constant of approximately 1 Nm<sup>-1\ufffd\ufffd</sup>but the design must differ considerably from that depicted in the game.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Hayley Jane Allison</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Roger Paul Leyser</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jordan Iain Penney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Giles Christopher Lipscombe</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-23</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-23</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/763">        <title>A2_5 Rotation Aviation</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/763</link>            <description>This paper investigates the feasibility of an aircraft flying using the Magnus efect by replacing its conventional wings with cylindrical wings that rotate. It is found that if the wings were to maintain roughly their current size, the minimum angular frequency required to create enough lift at take-off is 37.69 rad/s and at cruising speed is 8.58 rad/s.</description>            <dc:creator>James Anthony Farrow</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jeremy Hue</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Robert Miller</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Chris Checklin</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-26</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-26</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/723">        <title>A3_2 Sucking the sea dry</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/723</link>            <description><p>This paper discusses the possibility of removing water from the earth into space using only capillary action. The paper finds that a capillary of radius\ufffd\ufffd2.332x10^-10\ufffd\ufffdwould be required meaning that though theoretically possible not realistically plausible to create.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Gregor McQuade</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Michael Walker</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Lee Garland</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Thomas Bradley</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-27</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-27</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/778">        <title>P4_4 The Lunar Recession</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/778</link>            <description><p align="LEFT">This article investigates the Moon's recession from the Earth. The semi-major axis at which the Moon will become tidally locked with the Earth is calculated, and is found to be 558,000 km. It was found that the period of the Earth-Moon system would be about 48 current days long at this time. Using the Moon's current rate of recession, it was estimated that this process would happen in about 4.6 Gyr.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Lawrence Edward John Evans</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Daniel Cherrie</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Adam Tyler</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Luke Ingram</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-11-29</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-11-29</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/747">        <title>A3_5 Falling into Straw</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/747</link>            <description>The video game \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAssassin\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Creed\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd often depicts and encourages the player to leap off tall build-ings into bales of straw/hay. This article looks into whether this is survivable, and finds the maximum height to which the depicted hay bales are safe to jump into to be about a 12-13m fall, and the max survivable fall height to be about 50m.</description>            <dc:creator>Gregor McQuade</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Michael Walker</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Lee Garland</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Thomas Bradley</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-04</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-04</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/780">        <title>A4_9 It\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds not just Smoke and Mirrors</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/780</link>            <description>This paper looks at the feasbility of using wires too thin to be resolved by the human eye as a means of<br />making a stage magician float. It is found that for the two configurations tested, a stresses of 4.9 GPa<br />and 3.51 GPa would be exerted upon the wire. These are both notably more than the tensile strength<br />of steel, but not so high as to be unfeasable in the future. This doesn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt rule out wire in total though as<br />other combinations of wire and methods of consealment may be used.<br /><br /></description>            <dc:creator>Alexander Foden</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Adam Higgins</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Claire Sullivan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jonathan Sallabank</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-05</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-05</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/752">        <title>A2_3 Terraforming Mars: Creating a Magnetic Field</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/752</link>            <description><p>This paper investigates the possibility of generating a magnetic field on Mars by using a single turn coil. It was found that the current needed to create a magnetic field of similar magnitude to that of the Earth\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds is 9.47E8 A. In order for a cable of copper to be able to carry this current without melting it was found that it would need a radius of 70.4m. The power that is needed to run this coil was found to be 2.06E13 Js<sup>-1</sup> which is 121% of the power used on Earth every second.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Jeremy Hue</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>James Anthony Farrow</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Chris Checklin</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Robert Miller</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/776">        <title>A2_7 Natural Solar Panels</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/776</link>            <description>The paper looks at the possibility of retrieving energy from rain and how the energy collected compares to using solar panels instead. It is worked out that the maximum energy obtainable from the collection of rainwater is 2.67x10^9h J per day, where h is the height of the water above the ground. Compared to the Lieberose photovoltaic farm which would produce 6.5x10^11J in similar conditions making this imagined method likely unviable.</description>            <dc:creator>Jeremy Hue</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Robert Miller</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>James Anthony Farrow</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Chris Checklin</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/777">        <title>A2_6 Look at the size of that!</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/777</link>            <description>Further to the paper titled "Terraforming Mars: Creating a Magnetic Field" we investigate the size of the magnetopause that would be created by giving Mars a dipolar magnetic field. It is found that if the magnetic field at the equator is the same as that on Earth (31,000nT) then the stand-off distance of the magnetopause would be roughly 37000km.</description>            <dc:creator>James Anthony Farrow</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Robert Miller</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jeremy Hue</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Chris Checklin</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-08</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-08</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/710">        <title>P1_1 "Prepare for Titanfall"</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/710</link>            <description><p>In the popular digital entertainment title <em>Titanfall</em>, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdtitans\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, or large metal exoskeletons are dropped onto the battlefield on Earth, from a region in low earth orbit (LEO) at approximately 160 km. From start to finish, this process takes approximately 10 seconds in-game, subsequently requiring an average velocity of around 1.6<sub>x10</sub><sup>4</sup> ms<sup>-1</sup>. This paper aims to incorporate the often neglected aspect of quadratic drag into the dynamical calculations in order to show that the time required for this movement is closer to 223.2 seconds once the correct atmospheric impacts have been accounted for.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Daniel Treacher</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Luke Gene Holmes</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Christian Michelbach</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-09</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-09</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/731">        <title>P1_2 The Temperature of Jupiter</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/731</link>            <description><span style="font-family: 'Calibri','sans-serif'; font-size: 10pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA;">It is well known that there is a discrepancy between Jupiter\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds observed surface temperature, quantified through infrared emissions, and the theorised temperature based on the approximation that Jupiter acts as a black body. This paper will attempt to assess the additional contribution of three popular factors to the excess heat output of Jupiter; gravitational collapse, heat emission from radio-isotopes and the differentiation of He and H </span></description>            <dc:creator>Daniel Treacher</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Christian Michelbach</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Luke Gene Holmes</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-09</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-09</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/733">        <title>P1_3 The Double Pendulum and Lunar Seismometry</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/733</link>            <description><p>This paper aims to show that through the properties of the Laplace transformation into \ufffd\ufffd\ufffds\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd space, the coupled differential equations of the double pendulum, as shown in figure 1 [1] can be solved with relative ease and show interesting properties and applications of the system for variable values of gravity. These include lunar seismometry and consideration of similar experiments on other astronomical bodies.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Daniel Treacher</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Christian Michelbach</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Luke Gene Holmes</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-09</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-09</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/772">        <title>A5_10 An Interstellar Mess Up?</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/772</link>            <description>The paper investigates the physical implications behind the recent film Interstellar, surrounding the tidal forces acting on the planets orbiting the Supermassive Black Hole. The paper determines the minimum radii for each system to approach the structure, and finds that Earth-like planets could exist within the system, with a planet of Earth density corresponding to a Black Hole mass of 8x107 M\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. It is also found that the crew would be able to traverse the event horizon without damage to the spacecraft.</description>            <dc:creator>Jordan Iain Penney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Giles Christopher Lipscombe</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Roger Paul Leyser</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Hayley Jane Allison</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-09</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-09</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/754">        <title>A5_6 Pyramid of Geezers</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/754</link>            <description><p align="LEFT">\ufffd\ufffd</p><p><span style="font-size: small;">An investigation is conducted into the maximum size of the popular challenge, the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhuman pyramid\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. Under the assumption that the formation consists of people with perfect balance, the limitations upon the size therefore arise from the strength of the individuals. It is found that for a pyramid consisting of males of uniform mass, the maximum height is four tiers, potentially five if the individuals were marginally stronger than average. For a pyramid of men, women, and children, assembled with the highest mass on the base, the maximum achievable height was six tiers. </span></p></description>            <dc:creator>Hayley Jane Allison</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jordan Iain Penney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Roger Paul Leyser</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Giles Christopher Lipscombe</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-09</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-09</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/782">        <title>P1_6 Tipler Radiation Shielding</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/782</link>            <description><p align="LEFT">\ufffd\ufffd<span style="font-size: small;">This paper aims to investigate the use of copies of "Physics for Scientists and Engineers" by P. A. Tipler and G. Mosca to attenuate gamma rays. The number of copies of Tipler required to reduce a lethal beam of 100keV gamma rays delivering 8 Gy of radiation to a human being to a "safe" beam of 50 mGy was found to be 5 copies. </span></p></description>            <dc:creator>Luke Holmes</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Daniel Treacher</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Christian Michelbach</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/762">        <title>P1_5 Combating Global Warming With Orbital Transfers</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/762</link>            <description><p>In this paper, the orbital radius required to cool the Earth by 2K is determined using the Stefan-Boltzmann Law. The delta-V required to achieve this new orbital radius using a Hohmann Transfer manoeuvre is then determined and the mass of fuel required for such a manoeuvre is determined using Tsiolkovsky\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds rocket equation. The total mass of fuel required is found to be 0.04374 Earth masses.\ufffd\ufffd</p></description>            <dc:creator>Luke Holmes</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Christian Michelbach</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Daniel Treacher</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/767">        <title>P3_6 Would you like some tea?</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/767</link>            <description><span style="font-family: 'Calibri','sans-serif'; font-size: 10pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA;">This paper investigates the cooling rate of tea under two scenarios, leaving tea to sit by itself and stirring it. The calculation only factors in the heat loss from the top of the cup, neglecting heat loss via conduction through the sides. The results show that stirring the cup of tea would cool it 0.06 times faster than leaving it to cool on its own.</span></description>            <dc:creator>Poonam Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jessica Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Rutambhara Joshi</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/768">        <title>P3_7 Meltdown!</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/768</link>            <description><p align="LEFT"><span style="font-size: small;">This paper investigates the change in the albedo of the Earth due to the presence of sea ice and its impact on Earth's surface temperature. If all the sea ice melted, the albedo of the earth will increase by approximately 7.4%. This would result in an increase of surface temperature by approximately 6\ufffd\ufffdC. </span></p></description>            <dc:creator>Rutambhara Joshi</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Poonam Patel</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jessica Patel</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/746">        <title>A1_6 Critical Pressure Inside the Large Hadron Collider</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/746</link>            <description><p><!--StartFragment-->In the paper we examine the vacuum conditions inside the beam pipe at the Large Hadron Collider. A hypothetical degradation of the ultra-high vacuum by air particles is modelled. By considering the mean free path, we calculate the maximum pressure that would allow the accelerated protons to complete one lap of the accelerator without being scattered by gas particles. This threshold pressure is found to be 0.246 mbar.<!--EndFragment--></p></description>            <dc:creator>William Hunt Alexander Longman</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sam Turnpenney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Maria Garreffa</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Kieran Flatt</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/744">        <title>A1_7 Hunting for Monopoles i. A toy model for detection</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/744</link>            <description>Extensive searches for a magnetic monopole - the magnetic equivalent of a single electric charge - have been ongoing since they were first predicted by Paul Dirac in 1931. Despite strong theoretical foundations, these mysterious particles have never been detected with strong confidence. In this paper, we take advantage of Faraday's law to present a method for such searches: a monopole passing through a wire loop induces a current, which we calculate.</description>            <dc:creator>Kieran Flatt</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Maria Garreffa</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>William Longman</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sam Turnpenney</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/745">        <title>A1_8 Hunting for Monopoles ii. A retarding mechanism for magnetic charges</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/745</link>            <description>An earlier article in this journal discussed the possibility of detecting magnetic monopoles using a wire loop: when a magnetic monopole passes through the loop, a current is induced. It was remarked in that paper that a device to retard monopoles would be useful for assisting such searches. Here, we follow up this finding by investigating the feasibility of using a wire coil to perform such a task. It is found that such a device is unlikely given current technoloy.</description>            <dc:creator>Kieran Flatt</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Maria Garreffa</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>William Longman</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sam Turnpenney</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/729">        <title>A1_5 Laser Confinement of an Ideal Gas</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/729</link>            <description>Laser trapping is a technique used to confine atoms to a small region of space. In this paper, we look at this technique with regards to ideal gases. A relationship between the radius of the confined gas cloud and the power of laser required to confine it is derived.</description>            <dc:creator>Kieran Flatt</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Maria Garreffa</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Alexander Longman</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sam Turnpenney</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/753">        <title>P1_4 Global Warming: Effects on LEO Satellites</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/753</link>            <description><p>Satellites in low Earth orbits are subject to drag forces from the Earth\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds atmosphere, these forces deorbit the satellites over time. The effect of global warming on the rate at which a satellite will deorbit is investigated in this paper. It is found that, while a simplified model would predict a faster deorbit, this is not the case due to interactions at the molecular level.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Christian Michelbach</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Luke Holmes</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Dan Treacher</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/784">        <title>P1_8 Ice Ice, Maybe</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/784</link>            <description><p align="LEFT">\ufffd\ufffd</p><p><span style="font-size: small;">Many types of water ice can have semiconducting properties, particularly when doped, due to their crystalline structure. These properties may possibly lend the material to being used to create photovoltaic cells on distant planetary bodies. A band gap of 7.8 eV for cubic ice and 5.15 eV for ice XI give a solar spectral radiance of 1.51x10</span><span style="font-size: xx-small;">-11 </span><span style="font-size: small;">W sr</span><span style="font-size: xx-small;">-1 </span><span style="font-size: small;">m</span><span style="font-size: xx-small;">-2 </span><span style="font-size: small;">Hz</span><span style="font-size: xx-small;">-1 </span><span style="font-size: small;">and 9.45x10</span><span style="font-size: xx-small;">-10 </span><span style="font-size: small;">W sr</span><span style="font-size: xx-small;">-1 </span><span style="font-size: small;">m</span><span style="font-size: xx-small;">-2 </span><span style="font-size: small;">Hz</span><span style="font-size: xx-small;">-1 </span><span style="font-size: small;">respectively. This gives a very low amount of useful radiation at Europa and an even smaller amount 67P/Churyumov\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdGerasimenko, bringing extreme doubt on the use of this novel method. </span></p></description>            <dc:creator>Christian Michelbach</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Luke Holmes</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Dan Treacher</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-10</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-10</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/770">        <title>A5_8 A Great Punch Line</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/770</link>            <description><p>Leicester University has a prodigious history with its Karate Club and this paper investigates the total force transferred in a Karate punch and the mass limit needed for a person to be able to break wood with such a technique. The results show that the mass needed to overcome the Ultimate Tensile strength of wood is 104 kg.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Jordan Penney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Hayley Jane Allison</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Roger Paul Leyser</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Giles Christopher Lipscombe</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/711">        <title>P5_1 Light-ning Rod</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/711</link>            <description><p>The following paper aims to introduce the reader to the potential application of lasers as generators of paths of ionised gas that will act as lightning conductors in the event of a storm. Using a simple model of laser operation, values for energy, pulse duration and ultimately, power required have been calculated. While yielding no revolutionary data in the field of weather manipulation, the subject of this paper remains a valid source of research.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Ben Woodward</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Fracis Davies</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sabahuddin Humayun</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/756">        <title>P5_3 Liquid Lens</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/756</link>            <description><p>This paper investigates the possible manipulation of the capillary effect to manufacture small disposable lenses from a fluid. It concludes that, through the process of refraction, light can be made to focus or disperse. The factors that decide the behaviour of the light as it crosses the interface are identified as the ratio of refractive indices and the differences in surface tension.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Ben Woodward</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Francis Davies</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sabahudin Humayun</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/787">        <title>P5_5 Running in the Rain</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/787</link>            <description><p>This paper investigates the degree of wetness that a person would experience whilst travelling on foot through the rain in various weather conditions. It finds that moving as fast as possible when travelling during conditions with no wind, a headwind and a light tailwind is best to minimise how wet one gets. It also finds that in the case of a strong tailwind, it is best to match the speed of the wind to minimise this.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Francis Davies</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sabahudin Humayun</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Ben Woodward</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/765">        <title>A3_6 Pandora\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Floating Mountains: Rotational Momentum</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/765</link>            <description><p>This report follows a previous article [1], which looked into the physics of how to cause a mountain to float as depicted in the James Cameron movie \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAvatar\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. This article seeks to prove this is possible through the centrifugal force generated by the rotation of a planet. It was discovered that the necessary period of rotation, if that planet were Earth, was 13.4 minutes.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Lee Garland</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Gregor McQuade</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Michael Walker</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Thomas Bradley</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/769">        <title>A3_7 Pandora\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Floating Mountains: Lagrange Point</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/769</link>            <description><p>This article investigates the physical possibility of the floating mountains depicted in the film \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAvatar\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. It was theorised that should the L1 Lagrange point between the moon the movie was based on, and the gas giant it is shown to orbit lie on the surface of the planet, then any matter at that point should float. It was found that the planet would have to orbit very closely to the gas giant, within 0.6247 planetary radii of the surface, and would therefore be unfeasible in the manner depicted in the movie due to the natural disasters this would incur.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Gregor McQuade</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Lee Garland</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Michael Walker</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Thomas Bradley</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/766">        <title>A5_7 Neutron activation of the Unity Node of the ISS</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/766</link>            <description><p>The paper describes the calculation of the annual radiation dose of an astronaut on the ISS from gamma rays created by solar neutron activation of the aluminium structure of the Unity Node. It is calculated that the annual dose is 2.32 x 10<sup>-5</sup> mSv, and the solar neutron flux required to reach the maximum legal annual dose is 828 neutrons cm<sup>-3</sup> s<sup>-1</sup>. The results show that the annual neutron activation gamma ray dose is very small compared to the legal limit (some six orders of magnitude smaller).</p></description>            <dc:creator>Giles Lipscombe</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jordan Penney</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Hayley Jane Allison</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Roger Leyser</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/773">        <title>A4_8 The Power of Mjolnir</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/773</link>            <description>This paper calculates the maximum kinetic energy of Mjolnir can achieve being thrown by Thor and how much energy he can use from the redirection of lightning strikes during thunderstorms. The kinetic energy achieved from a throw was calculated to be 5.97 x 1018 J and the energy redirected from a single lightning flash was 108 J. It was also calculated that Thor could use the total power output of a thunderstorm equivalent to 2 x 1012 W.</description>            <dc:creator>Alex Foden</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Adam Higgins</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jonathan Sallabank</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Claire Sullivan</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/761">        <title>A4_7 Supermassive (Interstellar) Black Hole</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/761</link>            <description>This paper considers the plausibility of an event from the 2014 film Interstellar. It states that an hour on a planet orbiting a supermassive back hole is equivalent to 7 years passing on Earth. Calculations made state that the planet is inside the minimum orbit for a planet around a black hole and would thus fall with a ballistic trajectory into the centre.However, a static system was assumed, so with an optically spinning black hole the planet may be in a stable orbit. A spacecraft orbiting at a distance unaffected by time dilation is also considered and found to be largely implausible.</description>            <dc:creator>Claire Sullivan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jonathan Sallabank</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Alex Foden</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Adam Higgins</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/788">        <title>P5_6 A Hovering 747</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/788</link>            <description><p>The<em> </em><em>Halicarnassus</em> is a highly modified 747, capable of hovering, featured in Matthew Reilly\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds novel, <em>Seven Ancient Wonders</em>. The following paper examines this aircraft by first trying to validate its ability to hover with statistics from the components specified in the novel and then by proposing the use of solid rocket boosters instead. The feat accomplished in the novel of making the <em>Halicarnassus</em> hover is validated, an equation for the use of a solid fuel rocket is derived and an example of a solid rocket booster that exceeds the requirements placed upon it is found.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Ben Woodward</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Sabahudin Humayun</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Francis Davies</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/742">        <title>P5_2 Fluid Dynamics of a Near Supersonic Train</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/742</link>            <description><p>This paper investigates the effect on wind behaviour of allowing the trains of the London underground to accelerate to near super-sonic speeds i.e. Mach 0.9. The paper calculates the magnitude of the piston effect of a deep underground train arriving at a platform on a human and finds this value to be 67.7N of constant force.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Sabahuddin Humayun</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Francis Davies</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Ben Woodward</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-11</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-11</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/728">        <title>A4_3 The Human Barbecue</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/728</link>            <description><p align="LEFT">This paper considers the feasibility of the Human Torch, calculating the energy taken to turn a human body to plasma, generate a large amount of heat for long periods of time, and how much food would need to be consumed to provide the necessary energy. Johnny Storm's secondary power of absorbing thermal energy from his surroundings is also calculated as another way of fuelling his flames.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Jonathan Sallabank</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Claire Sullivan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Alex Foden</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Adam Higgins</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-12</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-12</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/781">        <title>A3_8 The Wings of Pegasus</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/781</link>            <description><div class="page" title="Page 1"><div class="layoutArea"><div class="column"><p><span>In this article a physical model is created to ascertain the size of the wings of the mythological flying horse Pegasus. Due to the nature of the physics involved, it was found that many assumptions had to be made that left some doubt for the quality of the final calculations. A minimum surface area of 7</span><span>.</span><span>9</span><span>m</span><span>2 </span><span>was calculated.\ufffd\ufffd</span></p></div></div></div></description>            <dc:creator>Thomas Bradley</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Gregor McQuade</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Lee Garland</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Michael Walker</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-12</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-12</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/758">        <title>A2_4 An (almost) ring of light</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/758</link>            <description><p>A potential method for causing light to travel a quasi-circular path by mimicking the shape of an N-sided polygon through a series of refraction events is discussed. Some simple geometric calculations are made in order to learn how this may be achieved and forms of intensity loss are considered. It is concluded that further analysis is required as there appears to be a trade-off between the beam losing too much energy and the refractive indices required being unphysical.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Robert Miller</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>James Anthony Farrow</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Chris Checklin</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Jeremy Hue</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-12</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-12</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/741">        <title>P2_3 Electric Armour</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/741</link>            <description><p>The validity of using a highly charged capacitor as \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdelectric armour\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd on light tanks is investigated. The capacitor discharges a large amount of energy into the incoming projectile, causing it to vaporise. It is found that a potential difference of 1kV is required to charge the capacitor to the desirable electric potential energy to vaporise the projectile.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Mark Phillips</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Katie Herlingshaw</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Duleep Vasudevan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Thomas Griffiths</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-12</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-12</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/775">        <title>P2_7 Magnetic Mayhem</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/775</link>            <description><p>This study calculates the increase in solar wind pressure required to compress the nose of the magnetopause of the Earth, down to its surface. It is found that the solar wind pressure would have to increase by at least a factor of \ufffd\ufffdto do this.</p></description>            <dc:creator>Mark Phillips</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Tom Griffiths</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Katie Herlingshaw</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Duleep Vasudevan</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-12</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-12</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>    <item rdf:about="https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/764">        <title>P2_6 The Breakfast Club</title>    <link>https://physics.le.ac.uk/journals/index.php/pst/article/view/764</link>            <description>This paper investigates the sonic boom generated by crunchy foods. Specifically, the force required to tip over an empty cereal box 0.1 m from a person\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds mouth is calculated to be 8.37x10^-10 N. It would take the force of 29 million people crunching in unison to generate the required 2.45x10^-2 N to tip over the box.</description>            <dc:creator>Katie Herlingshaw</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Duleep Vasudevan</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Thomas Griffiths</dc:creator>        <dc:creator>Mark Phillips</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-12-14</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2014-12-14</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>13</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>          </item>  </rdf:RDF>
